articles.headline: Fed Officials Tamp Down Overheating Worries as Investors Fret
articles.snippet: Markets gyrated this week on concern that the Federal Reserve may lift rates earlier. But its policymakers stuck with their patient script on Wednesday.
articles.abstract: Markets gyrated this week on concern that the Federal Reserve may lift rates earlier. But its policymakers stuck with their patient script on Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inflation jitters are popping up in earnings call chatter, spooking investors and dominating business television talk shows. One place they aren’t taking over, it appears, is the Federal Reserve.

articles.headline: British Political Veteran Steers Facebook’s Trump Decision
articles.snippet: Nick Clegg, a former deputy prime minister, has shaped the company’s handling of Donald Trump at every turn.
articles.abstract: Nick Clegg, a former deputy prime minister, has shaped the company’s handling of Donald Trump at every turn.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Facebook barred President Donald J. Trump from its service in January, Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive, defended the decision in a Facebook post the morning after the siege of the Capitol. But the first draft was written the night before by Nick Clegg, a former British deputy prime minister who leads the company’s public affairs.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: Biden Leans Into Plans to Tax the Rich
articles.snippet: “We’re not going to deprive any of these executives of their second or third home, travel privately by jet,” the president said at the White House.
articles.abstract: “We’re not going to deprive any of these executives of their second or third home, travel privately by jet,” the president said at the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden delivered a clear and punchy message to America’s highest earners on Wednesday: I’m going to raise your taxes, but your vacation homes are safe.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Annie Karni

articles.headline: Taking ‘Extraordinary Measures,’ Biden Backs Suspending Patents on Vaccines
articles.snippet: The Biden administration, siding with some world leaders over the U.S. pharmaceutical industry, came out in favor of waiving intellectual property protections for coronavirus vaccines.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration, siding with some world leaders over the U.S. pharmaceutical industry, came out in favor of waiving intellectual property protections for coronavirus vaccines.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration came out on Wednesday in support of waiving intellectual property protections for coronavirus vaccines, siding with international efforts to bolster production amid concerns about vaccine access in developing nations.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Rebecca Robbins

articles.headline: In Turning on Liz Cheney, G.O.P. Bows to Trump’s Election Lies
articles.snippet: House Republicans were lobbying to replace Representative Liz Cheney, who has vocally called out Donald J. Trump’s lies, with Representative Elise Stefanik, who has embraced them.
articles.abstract: House Republicans were lobbying to replace Representative Liz Cheney, who has vocally called out Donald J. Trump’s lies, with Representative Elise Stefanik, who has embraced them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Top Republicans moved swiftly on Wednesday to purge Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming from their leadership ranks for vocally rejecting Donald J. Trump’s election lies, laying the groundwork to install a replacement who has embraced his false claims of voting fraud.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Catie Edmondson

articles.headline: Facebook’s ‘Supreme Court’ Tells Zuckerberg He’s the Decider
articles.snippet: The company tried to punt its Trump dilemma to a panel of experts. On Wednesday, the experts punted back.
articles.abstract: The company tried to punt its Trump dilemma to a panel of experts. On Wednesday, the experts punted back.
articles.lead_paragraph: There’s a saying plastered on the walls of Facebook’s headquarters in Menlo Park, Calif.: “Nothing at Facebook is somebody else’s problem.”

articles.headline: ‘Turning the Corner’: U.S. Covid Outlook Reaches Most Hopeful Point Yet
articles.snippet: Cases and deaths have dipped, and vaccinations make scientists hopeful, even as variants mean the coronavirus is here to stay.
articles.abstract: Cases and deaths have dipped, and vaccinations make scientists hopeful, even as variants mean the coronavirus is here to stay.
articles.lead_paragraph: After weeks of coronavirus patients flooding emergency rooms in Michigan, the worst Covid-19 hot spot in the nation, hospitalizations are finally falling.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Sarah Mervosh

articles.headline: The Lithium Gold Rush: Inside the Race to Power Electric Vehicles
articles.snippet: A race is on to produce lithium in the United States, but competing projects are taking very different approaches to extracting the vital raw material. Some might not be very green.
articles.abstract: A race is on to produce lithium in the United States, but competing projects are taking very different approaches to extracting the vital raw material. Some might not be very green.
articles.lead_paragraph: Atop a long-dormant volcano in northern Nevada, workers are preparing to start blasting and digging out a giant pit that will serve as the first new large-scale lithium mine in the United States in more than a decade — a new domestic supply of an essential ingredient in electric car batteries and renewable energy.
articles.byline: By Ivan Penn, Eric Lipton and Gabriella Angotti-Jones

articles.headline: Opposition to Net Neutrality Was Faked, New York Says
articles.snippet: The state attorney general’s office reached an agreement that levies millions in penalties on third-party services that generated the comments.
articles.abstract: The state attorney general’s office reached an agreement that levies millions in penalties on third-party services that generated the comments.
articles.lead_paragraph: Internet service providers funded an effort that yielded millions of fake comments supporting the Federal Communications Commission’s repeal of so-called net neutrality rules in 2017, the New York attorney general said on Thursday.
